SPEECH.PARA: I rise to support Senator Tambling's motion. I want to deal with paragraph (a) of that motion. I begin by addressing some comments to the second part of the Democrats' amendment moved by Senator Kernot. In some respects it is a pity that one cannot amend that motion because at least one could correct the spelling mistake. I want to deal with a much more serious matter. I believe—and I hope Senator Kernot listens very carefully to what I have to say—that Senator Kernot's presentation in this place was the most dishonest I have ever heard from her. I do not usually stand here and attack the Democrats, but for Senator Kernot to come in here and spend three-quarters of her time attacking us on the terms of that motion—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I didn't.

—Yes, you did. You should read your own speech. Before the last election, Senator Kernot consistently attacked our approach in relation to changing the taxation system, changing government expenditure and a whole range of things. She led the charge in that attack, and it is well and truly on the public record. I will go back and quote some of the things that she said at that time. Senator Kernot does herself no good, she does this parliament no good, and she does nothing for the Australian people when she comes in here and misrepresents the situation.

PARA.TAB: I am sure government members would agree that she sided with the government prior to the last election. She consistently attacked the opposition's policy prescription. She consistently attacked us. She did not attack the government. She supported the government. She consistently supports the government in this place. That is her choice. If she decides to be part of the government, that is her decision. She did it in terms of raising fuel excise. She did it in terms of raising sales tax. Let us get some of these facts on the table and be quite honest about them. If she makes that decision, that is her choice. She should not come in here and try to pretend that it was something else. That is exactly what she did and she should read her words very carefully.

Recently, she was in North Queensland complaining about the increase in the price of fuel. She was part of the process that put up fuel excise by 6c. Let us look at this government in terms of fuel excise. In question time today and yesterday, Senator Collins talked about ANL. Under his stewardship, $290 million, or thereabouts, has gone down the drain in the last three or four years. I do not know when we will find out the figures but, since 1992, this government, supported by the Democrats, has put up fuel excise from 7c to 32c. Senator Kernot did that. She has been part of that.

Because the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Alexander Downer, or Mr John Howard, or somebody else raises a matter for public debate, she turns around and says that there has been a commitment made in terms of expenditure. In effect, that is what she said today. She named all these things. These are policy options that have to be put in this place. For example, when Senator Schacht stands up in this place and raises a particular issue, he has not suddenly made a commitment to go out and o spend some money on that issue. There has to be a policy debate and so on. Senator Kernot came in here today and totally misrepresented the position for her own fancy little political purposes. She was quite dishonest in what she did. I am very disappointed that she chose that route.

I want to deal with the first part of our motion which, surprisingly, is the part the Democrats want to get rid of. I consider this to be the most important part of this motion because it goes to the crux of the problem in the Australian economy. I know the housing industry is very important. I know the impact of interest rates on people in the housing industry is very important. But the impact of interest rates and lax fiscal policy is far more damaging on business, particularly small business, and it is particularly damaging on the rural sector, as is the fuel excise. It is all very well to say that we have a fuel excise and we apply it equally across the board, but if a person drives only five miles to work and home once a day it has very little impact.

However, if one has to get all of one's goods and services carted hundreds, if not thousands, of miles, it has an enormous impact. I heard evidence last week in Darwin that 23 per cent of the cost of carting cattle in the Northern Territory is the result of fuel excise. My colleague Senator Panizza comes from Southern Cross in Western Australia: fuel excise adds $4 a tonne to the cost of carting grain from Southern Cross to Kwinana. The fuel excise has an horrendous impact on cartage costs. Those particular areas can get 14 inches of rain and the growers are looking at an increase in costs of between $20,000 and $40,000 a year, just on that one item alone. This tax was originally for road funding, yet it is being spent on railway lines. It just does not make sense. It is poor public policy. The government must start recognising this.

A couple of days ago Senator Brownhill introduced a matter of public importance condemning the government for its handling of the drought. However, it is far more than the impact of the drought; it is the impact of being screwed into the ground. Rural debt is now above $17 billion. The increase of 0.75 per cent in interest rates will add another $120 million overnight to the cost of servicing that debt. Government members do not seem to understand the impact of that increase, which will further drive people into the ground, destroy them and emotionally cut them in half.

It does not matter whether interest rates increase from five per cent to six per cent or from 13 per cent to 14 per cent: the impact is the same. The problem is caused by the irresponsible fiscal management of this government. In my view, through overspending this government is putting so much pressure on the financial markets that Australia has real interest rates that are as high as anywhere else in the world. It is all very well to say that we have an official rate of 5.5 per cent or whatever it is—it is somewhere around that—but out in the marketplace people are paying more like 10 per cent to 14 per cent: those are the real interest rates.

With regard to fiscal management, cutting expenditure and reducing the deficit, we are well and truly on the public record, even back immediately after the last election, as saying that it was very important that the government tackle that particular aspect of public policy in this country. Writing in the Age today, David McKenzie states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Reserve Bank and the Federal Government have indicated that further small increases in interest rates are probable to make sure the economy does not overheat.
However, in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald, Ross Gittins states:

PARA.TAB: Never before has the board of the Reserve Bank been so outspoken about an aspect of economic policy outside its responsibility. Never before has the Governor of the Reserve, Bernie Fraser, been so openly critical of the Government's performance.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are fairly cutting words from a person in that position. Those words should ring alarm bells for government members.

PARA.TAB: The opposition is gravely concerned that Australia is going back into another one of its boom-bust cycles. The opposition is greatly concerned that the very people who face the horrendous problem of debt in trying to get out of the adverse seasonal conditions will be further damaged and screwed into the ground. Let us look at the last five years, from 1991 through to 1994-95: all broadacre farmers have had average total losses of $82,279.

The wheat and coarse grain crop industry was the only industry which made any money during that period. It made $33,336, according to ABARE's estimates of farm business profit. That is only $6,000 a year, and that industry is the only one that made a profit. That is not much money to run the business, repair fences, build dams, fix the guttering on the house and all the other things that have to be done. I put it to those people on the other side of the chamber and to Senator Kernot that these matters have to be addressed. They cannot go on.

If we look at mixed livestock and crops, we see that their losses over the last five years are $76,166. If we look at the sheep industry, which primarily involves woolgrowers—as I have said many times before in this place, I have an interest in this industry; my son is now on the property—we see that it has lost $147,920. If we look at the beef industry, we see that it has lost $55,530. Queensland, which is represented by Senator O'Chee, is the largest beef producer in this country. I think Western Australia is the second largest beef producer, but Queensland is certainly the largest.

The sheep and beef industry has lost $101,244. Unfortunately, I do not have the figures for the dairy industry. Hopefully, it is doing a little better than the other industries that I have mentioned. The government cannot go on ignoring the fact that its fiscal policy has forced up real interest rates and kept them up there. The impact that is having on the sectors is quite horrendous. In fact, it is horrifying. When people appearing before a committee looking into the drought or the rural adjustment situation break down in tears and cry in front of us, we as parliamentarians have to ask ourselves what the hell is going on, particularly when these people are the third or fourth generation on the land and have done nothing wrong. They have worked hard all their lives. They need a break, and this government needs to address the problem very quickly.

Those people opposite are in power, not us, and they need to address the problem. Providing about $14 million of rural adjustment at this late stage—nobody will knock that back; the people who get the support will be grateful—amounts to about one leaf in a big pot for boiling tea. They have to address longer term fiscal management in the rural sector. They have to address the cost of transport. They have to address the impact of the fuel excise. They have to address the impact of sales tax to see where it falls and who picks it up.

When we look at the distribution of some of these decisions, we see that it falls very unfairly on a small group of people. I want to turn back to the wool industry for a moment. Just last year—thank God—wool prices picked up a little. It looks as though a lot of people will break even this year. Last year people were losing $5 a sheep—they were keeping in there—yet they put $3 1/2 billion into the Australian economy. People have to ask themselves some questions in terms of that situation. How far do we let people go down before we address the particular issue? How many more people will commit suicide because they cannot handle the particular pressures placed on them?

I know that this is emotional, heart-rending stuff, but the rate of youth suicide in rural areas is six times higher than the national average. We have to ask ourselves some very serious questions. We have to look into our hearts as well as our heads. We have to look at the distribution and see who gets hit by the policies because what is happening out there is not very nice. In fact, it is damned distasteful.

In our recent trips around Australia with the rural and regional affairs committee, we heard some very heart-rending stories not only from the farming sector but also from the support industries. The government needs to address the question of whether there is a place for a proper IED scheme and a range of other policy options for small businesses. I say to those opposite that time is running out for many people. It is running out not only for them and their families but for many of their employees. I have talked to people who have worked on properties for 20 and 25 years. They no longer have a job, a home or anywhere to go, yet we consistently hear in this place how wonderfully well we are doing and about this brilliant recovery that we are experiencing. The recovery is very uneven.

We have already seen the impact of the first two budgets since the last election with our first increase in interest rates. The warning signs were given not only from those on this side of the chamber but also from business leaders. It is essential for restructuring that there be a more dynamic approach to workplace reform. I will not debate that subject now other than to make that statement. I have debated it before and I will do so again.

Why do we come into this place and repeat the same message time and again? Why did the rural and regional affairs committee review into rural adjustment receive almost identical evidence to that received in 1992? We will come to almost identical recommendations. Why have most of those recommendations been ignored? Questions should be asked as to why some of these issues have not been addressed, particularly when the committee has taken a bipartisan approach.

There is a very serious financial and emotional problem in most of rural Australia at this time. This parliament, particularly those opposite, cannot continue to ignore it. If they continue to ignore it, there will be a real strip-down of the infrastructure of our great country.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion canvasses the government's callousness when it comes to the economy and to those who are borrowing to buy homes or struggling to pay off the debt on their farms. This motion deals directly with one of the most lamentable failures of this government's economic policy: the inevitable rise which we saw recently of 0.75 per cent in official interest rates.

PARA.TAB: That rise in interest rates was inevitable from the very moment that the Treasurer (Mr Willis) delivered his budget. We were doomed to face higher interest rates because this government was unwilling to curtail its massive spending and massive borrowing, which can do nothing but wreak havoc on this country's economy.

I recall very well sitting in the lock-up on the day the budget was to be delivered and looking at the budget papers with dismay and despair and saying, `It is inevitable that interest rates will rise.' I wrote an article for the National Party's budget special which said, `Why this budget will make your home loan dearer.' It does not bring me any great satisfaction to say it, but I was right, because this government is spending well beyond its means with deficits of over $11 billion to $12 billion.

Yet those opposite seem to be congratulating themselves. They stand with a hand on their hearts and say, `Aren't we wonderful people because we are cutting the deficit?' People in Australia seem to think that that means the government is cutting its debt; in fact, it is not. Every year that this government runs a deficit the amount of money the government has to borrow increases. Government debt goes up because this year's deficit will be added to last year's deficit and the deficit of the year before, and next year's deficit will be added on top of that. That is why government debt in recent years has trebled in the space of just a couple of years.

It stands to reason that when the government borrows large amounts of money the price of money will go up, and the price of money is the interest rate. The government is out there greedily soaking up the savings that Australians have put away—very small amounts of savings, I hasten to add. The consequence of too much demand for money and not enough supply is that the price goes up.

It is just like the price of spuds. If lots and lots of people want to buy spuds but there are not many available, the price of spuds will go up. If there is lots of demand to borrow money—in this case, mainly coming from the government—but very little capacity to save it, to make that money available, because the budget papers themselves admit that saving is at an historic low in Australia at the moment, it stands to reason that the price of money will go up as well. That is why this government's last budget made it inevitable that interest rates would go up and that struggling Australian families with mortgages and struggling Australian farmers would pay the cost for this government's economic folly.

It is folly because this government has a hypocritical policy when it comes to the economy. At the same time that it is busily spending far more than it actually receives—spending $11 billion or $12 billion more than it will receive—

TALK.START.PARA: —$12,000 million.

—As Senator Tambling rightly interjects, $12,000 million. The government is saying to the ordinary Australian, `We are going to put up interest rates because we think you're spending too much and we're going to make it more difficult for you.' The government says to ordinary people trying to buy a house, `We think too many people are buying houses. That's why we are going to put up interest rates.' Yet, at the same time, it does nothing to curtail its own out-of-control spending.

PARA.TAB: Is it not hypocrisy for a government to say, `We will spend without regard for our capacity to bring in income, yet you, in the Australian community, must curtail your spending because we think you're spending too much.'? Are people spending too much on houses? I think the answer is no. Certainly there has been a big drop in the rate of growth in home finance in this country. It has slowed down quite remarkably, as Senator Tambling's motion ably says.

Let us look at the consequence of this government's increase in interest rates. Let us take a hypothetical couple who have just bought a house. We will call them Greg and Di. They have been saving for two years. They have made the deposit on their house, probably with money they borrowed from their parents. They can fund the loan at the moment and they fix the loan for the first 12 months.

However, there is a common clause in fixed loans, when they are capped for the first 12 months, that they cannot be repaid at a faster rate. So they have just signed the papers on the house. They are spared the increase in interest rates for 12 months, but what is their first thought? Their first thought is, goodness gracious, interest rates are going up three-quarters of a per cent now, what will they be in six months time? Another half a per cent? So they start to save every penny they have so that as soon as the 12 months is over they can make a big payment to reduce the mortgage—$3,000 or $4,000—so that they do not have to pay a higher rate of interest on a big loan.

The consequence of that inevitably will be that a lot of demand will be taken out of the economy, not just in the housing sector, but elsewhere. I think one of the real dangers of this increase in interest rates is that it is going to stop the spending on consumer durables. In other words, people will not buy a washing machine, a dishwasher or a drier. They might save that money to put into the mortgage, which will result in fewer jobs and fewer opportunities for people who are unemployed. That is the consequence of this government's policy and that is why its policy is so hopelessly flawed.

Let us turn to the rural sector. What impact will this increase in interest rates have on the rural sector? The government congratulates itself on having made $15 million available to help farmers who are struggling with the drought to meet the interest payments on their farm loans because they have no capacity to pay at the moment. As Senator Crane has so ably said, many farmers have made losses year after year because of the drought and this government's failed economic policy. But what will this interest rate increase do to those people? It will wipe out the value of that $15 million that the government has offered in drought relief, because a three-quarters of a per cent increase in interest rates will add $120 million in interest to the amount which the farm sector has to pay this year. So the government is saying, `Aren't we wonderful, generous, compassionate people? We're going to give you $15 million to help you with the drought.' In the very same week we see interest rates go up by three-quarters of a per cent, which will add $120 million to the amount which struggling farmers will have to repay this year.

I hasten to add that much of that farm debt exists in states which are drought stricken. The despair in my state of Queensland is frightening, as is the despair in New South Wales, which will shortly be 80 per cent drought stricken, and down into western Victoria—

TALK.START.PARA: —And Western Australia.

—And Western Australia, too. All of those people have no capacity to pay because the drought has forced them in many cases to take all the stock off the property. Many of those people will have a big task in front of them in trying to rebuild their herds and flocks. They have had to cull the females because they cannot carry them any more and they are desperate for the money. If people look at the price of culled cows, they will see what I am talking about. Those people will be hit by higher interest rates and a higher interest bill which far outweighs anything the government has done to help them. In fact, the government's response to this drought has been pitiful and disgusting. The despair is added to by this increase in interest rates. That is the consequence of this government's policy, and it should be condemned for it.

PARA.TAB: Let us also look at what it is doing to investment, particularly in the housing sector. I refer, for example, to Cairns, where I live. Finally, we are seeing some increase in housing in Cairns. Senator Tambling well knows that housing in Cairns has been unaffordable for many people for a long period. In fact, a friend of mine who moved there with his wife—he was working at Qantas; his wife was working at David Jones until she had a baby—was forced to move out of Cairns because he could not afford the rent. His wife was unable to work because she was looking after the baby and he just was not bringing in enough money to pay the bills. So finally, we have seen an increase in the amount of available housing and that increase will be wiped out by these high interest rates.

People who have made an investment in the housing market in Cairns will see their investment annihilated by these increases in interest rates. I suspect that many of the people who bought investment properties and who were guaranteed a certain rate of return may find that that guarantee is worthless. Obviously, unless there is a demand for that housing, there will be no way that the housing company can meet that guarantee and people will lose money.

That is the consequence of this government's failure—people will lose money. I am not just talking about speculators; I am talking about honest people who borrowed to buy their first home. What could be more disheartening, what could be more frightening, than to be a young couple who saved to buy a house, who find interest rates going up, who have a child and who find that their capacity to pay is reduced and, ultimately, find that they have to sell the house and suffer a loss because of a heartless government policy?

That is what we are talking about, and that is why this government roundly deserves to be condemned by the Senate and by all Australians for the callousness and heartlessness which it has shown towards people who are saving to buy their own homes. What we see today inevitably had to follow from the budget, but what worries me even more is that this government has not learnt from the last recession it induced in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't shout, Bill. We can hear you. You don't have to shout.

—We see honourable senators on the other side shouting and interjecting because they do not want to listen to the truth. The truth is that Senator Murphy's government brought this economy to its knees and it is about to repeat that same crime in the next couple of years if the Australian people are foolish enough ever to re-elect it. That is the crime which it has perpetrated and that is the crime we on this side of the chamber are fighting.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson argued month after month, year after year, against increases in interest rates which the government imposed on the Australian economy. Senator Watson was here sounding the warnings. Did we hear the government heed the message? Of course not, because it has no understanding of what it is like to be an ordinary Australian.

This government is so pitifully out of touch that Senator Murphy even now finds it a joke that we are debating the high interest rates which his government is imposing on young Australians saving to buy houses, the high interest rates which his government is imposing upon farmers. Senator Murphy can laugh because he is not dependent on the farm sector any more; Senator Murphy is no longer dependent upon what happens in the shearing industry. Senator Murphy has his comfortable seat in the Senate. But there are a lot of station hands and a lot of shearers and a lot of wool classers who will not have jobs this year because of the increase in interest rates.

A mate of mine is a wool classer. He cannot get a job. He knows very well that this increase in interest rates makes it more difficult for farmers to make ends meet, which means more and more people will do the shearing or the classing themselves and there will be fewer and fewer jobs out there in the farm sector. So much for the care and compassion that Senator Murphy once held for the workers in the farm industry. Once he gets in here he finds the invitation of the red leather all too appealing.

Enough of Senator Murphy. Enough of despair. I believe that we should offer Australia an alternative. The alternative will be on offer at the next election. The honourable senators on the other side will see exactly what Australia thinks of their failed economic policies when they get thrown out on their ear at the next election. But until then I endorse this motion. I endorse Senator Tambling's solid and cohesive condemnation of this government and urge the Senate to adopt his motion.
